definition: Periodic written evaluation of reasonably foreseeable internal and external risks to customer information security, confidentiality, integrity, and availability, with assessment of existing safeguard sufficiency, identification of gaps and weaknesses, and prioritization of risks for remediation. Foundation of information security program (Safeguards Rule Element 2).
official_description: Safeguards Rule 16 CFR 314.4(b) mandates periodic written risk assessment as foundational Element 2 of the information security program. Risk assessment must: (1) Identify reasonably foreseeable internal risks including insider threats, employee errors, system failures, process weaknesses, human mistakes, fraud by employees, negligence; (2) Identify reasonably foreseeable external risks including cyber attacks, malware, phishing, social engineering, data theft, DDoS attacks, ransomware, zero-day exploits, supply chain compromise, physical theft, natural disasters; (3) Evaluate likelihood (probability) of each identified threat - how likely to occur based on threat frequency data, industry trends, institution's exposure level, attacker motivation and capability, preventive controls effectiveness; (4) Evaluate potential impact (damage/harm) of each threat - confidentiality impact (unauthorized disclosure), integrity impact (unauthorized modification), availability impact (loss of access/service), financial impact, reputational impact, regulatory impact, customer harm; (5) Assess confidentiality, integrity, availability (CIA triad) of customer information and systems - what information, systems, and processes require highest protection; (6) Evaluate sufficiency of existing safeguards and controls - are current technical, administrative, physical controls adequate to mitigate risk to acceptable level; identify gaps and weaknesses; (7) Categorize and prioritize risks based on likelihood × impact calculation - critical, high, medium, low severity; (8) Document how identified risks will be treated - mitigate (implement controls), accept (tolerate), transfer (insurance, outsource), avoid (eliminate activity); (9) Result drives entire security program - safeguard selection and implementation prioritized by risk. Assessment should follow structured framework (NIST Risk Management Framework, NIST SP 800-30, ISO 27005, ISO 31000) using consistent evaluation criteria and scoring methodology. Assessment must cover all systems and processes handling customer information including those managed by third parties/service providers.
applicable_to: All financial institutions under Safeguards Rule; conducted by or under oversight of Qualified Individual (CISO/Security Officer); involves cross-functional participation from: IT and security teams, operations teams, business unit leaders, compliance and legal, internal audit, vendors/service providers, external consultants (if needed); applies to all systems, data, processes handling customer information; geographic scope includes all locations

definition: Process of systematically identifying and documenting all reasonably foreseeable internal and external threats to customer information security, confidentiality, integrity, and availability, serving as foundation for likelihood assessment and risk prioritization.
official_description: Threat identification is first step of risk assessment process per NIST Risk Management Framework and NIST SP 800-30. Comprehensive threat identification ensures all significant risks captured and evaluated. Threats may be categorized as internal vs. external, intentional vs. accidental, technological vs. physical, contemporary vs. emerging. Threat identification should be comprehensive using multiple sources: historical incident data, industry data, threat intelligence, stakeholder interviews, brainstorming sessions. Should avoid bias toward known threats and ensure emerging threats captured.

definition: Evaluation of the probability or frequency with which identified threats will occur to customer information and systems, considering threat actor capability, motivation, vulnerabilities, existing controls, and historical incident data. Foundation for risk prioritization.
official_description: Likelihood assessment evaluates probability of threat occurrence. Assessment should be evidence-based using historical data, industry data, threat intelligence, not subjective guesses. Likelihood evaluated separately for each identified threat. Likelihood × Impact = Risk prioritization. Should consider current state of controls (does institution have mitigations affecting likelihood).
applicable_to: All financial institutions conducting risk assessment; applies to all identified threats; cross-functional involvement in evaluation; subject matter experts for specific threat areas
organization_owner: Risk assessment team (Qualified Individual leads); Security team for cyber threat likelihood; Operations team for process-based threats; Compliance for regulatory threats; External threat intelligence providers; Financial analyst for cost assessment; Security consultants for expertise
version: NIST SP 800-30 Risk Assessment methodology; NIST SP 800-39; probability estimation techniques; threat intelligence sources; historical incident frequency data
status: Ongoing evaluation; updated upon discovery of new incidents; updated upon threat landscape changes; re-evaluated as controls implemented; annual reassessment minimum
key_features: Evaluation Approaches: Quantitative Approach: assign probability scores (e.g., 0-1.0, 0-100%); calculate based on incident frequency data; likelihood = incidents per year / total exposures; example: 1 breach per 100 institutions annually = 1% likelihood; example: 5 attempted hacks per system annually = high frequency = 60%+ likelihood; Qualitative Approach: assign probability categories: very likely (75-100%), likely (50-74%), possible (25-49%), unlikely (1-24%), rare (<1%); based on judgment and expert opinion; may be more practical for many threats; Semi-quantitative Approach: scoring rubric for likelihood evaluation; factors weighted and scored; total score maps to probability range; structured qualitative approach; Historical Frequency: review institution's incident history; how many times has threat occurred in past 3-5 years; frequency trends (increasing, stable, decreasing); similar institutions' frequency; industry frequency data; Industry Data Sources: Verizon Data Breach Investigations Report (annual); IBM Cost of Data Breach Report; World Economic Forum Global Risks Report; Gartner security reports; official_description: Impact assessment evaluates harm resulting from threat occurrence. Impact × Likelihood = Risk prioritization. Higher impact risks warrant stronger mitigation efforts.

definition: Systematic ranking of identified risks based on combined assessment of likelihood and impact, determining which risks require immediate mitigation, which can be monitored, and which may be accepted based on institutional risk appetite and resources.
official_description: Risk prioritization determines mitigation priority and resource allocation. High likelihood/high impact risks receive highest priority (mitigate immediately). Low likelihood/low impact risks lower priority (may accept). Should align with institution's risk appetite and resource constraints. Enables efficient resource allocation for maximum risk reduction.
